title: Schorfheide-Chorin Biosphere Reserve
text:
The Schorfheide-Chorin Biosphere Reserve, often shortened to Schorfheide, is a <a href="biosphere%20reserve">biosphere reserve</a> in the <a href="States%20of%20Germany">German State</a> of <a href="Brandenburg">Brandenburg</a> near the <a href="Poland">Polish</a> border. The reserve was established on 1 October 1990 following the <a href="German%20Reunification">German Reunification</a> and is under the protection of the <a href="UNESCO">UNESCO</a> <a href="Man%20and%20Biosphere%20Reserve%20Programme">Man and Biosphere Reserve Programme</a>. It stretches over the <a href="Districts%20of%20Germany">German districts</a> of <a href="Barnim">Barnim</a>, <a href="Uckermark">Uckermark</a>, <a href="M%C3%A4rkisch-Oderland">Märkisch-Oderland</a> and <a href="Oberhavel">Oberhavel</a> and incorporates an area of . Notable towns are <a href="Eberswalde">Eberswalde</a>, <a href="Joachimsthal%2C%20Brandenburg">Joachimsthal</a> and <a href="Friedrichswalde">Friedrichswalde</a>. The core area of the reserve is formed by the Schorfheide forest, one of the largest cohesive woodlands in Germany.
History.
From the <a href="Early%20Middle%20Ages">Early Middle Ages</a> until the period of the <a href="Thirty%20Years%27%20War">Thirty Years' War</a>, the area fell under the responsibility of the cloister of <a href="Chorin">Chorin</a> which led to a cultivation of suitable spaces. Forest clearances took place for the sake of producing weapons for the <a href="Prussia">Prussia</a>n army, but the woods were usually afforested. Large parts of the woodland were left untouched as hunting areas for the nobility, which marked the creation of today's wilderness. During the <a href="Third%20Reich">Third Reich</a>, <a href="Hermann%20G%C3%B6ring">Hermann Göring</a> chose the spot for his country residence "<a href="Carinhall">Carinhall</a>". After <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, the forests were again used as an exclusive hunting and leisure area for the <a href="German%20Democratic%20Republic">East German</a> leaders. The title of a Biosphere Reserve was awarded in 1990 following an initiative of then East German head of state <a href="Lothar%20de%20Maizi%C3%A8re">Lothar de Maizière</a>.
Nature and biology.
The Schorfheide was formed during the <a href="Quaternary%20glaciation">last ice age</a>. Today it is a <a href="cultural%20landscape">cultural landscape</a> composed of extensive woodlands (most of which are dominated by either <a href="oak">oak</a>s or <a href="pine">pine</a>s), a wide range of bodies of standing water like lakes (most notably <a href="Werbellinsee">Werbellinsee</a>, <a href="Grimnitzsee">Grimnitzsee</a> and <a href="Parsteiner%20See">Parsteiner See</a>), ponds and renaturated <a href="bog">bog</a>s, as well as <a href="Heath%20%28habitat%29">heathlands</a>. Some parts of the Schorfheide are left as a <a href="wilderness">wilderness</a>. The reserve is crossed by the river <a href="Rag%C3%B6se">Ragöse</a>.
The Schorfheide-Chorin Biosphere Reserve is home of many forest-living animals like <a href="red%20deer">red deer</a> and <a href="wild%20boar">wild boar</a>s. Of special interest and goal of protection are those animals whose habitats are endangered elsewhere in Germany like <a href="beaver">beaver</a>s, <a href="European%20otter">otters</a>, <a href="European%20pond%20terrapin">pond tortoises</a> and <a href="European%20fire-bellied%20toad">fire-bellied toads</a>. Due to its water bodies, the area serves as an important breeding and resting ground for birds like <a href="white-tailed%20eagle">white-tailed eagle</a>s and <a href="common%20crane">cranes</a>.
